channel.title: Having problems with my car
channel.description:
C&Ped from another forum :)
In the past week or so I've been having a couple of problems with my Fiesta and I'm not sure if it's something I should have properly looked at or something I could possibly fix myself. I'm hoping that one of you might be able to suggest potential problems/solutions.
Basically, I did about a 300 mile journey the other week, and when I got in my car the next day, I could feel that it wasn't running right. The engine was idling at around 900-1000rpm, there was a lot of vibration coming from the car and the exhaust sounded really odd, almost like it was chugging. I looked at the exhaust and it seemed really loose, so I thought initially it could be the exhaust clip. Also, there has definitely been a significant loss of power, especially at lower revs.
So the next day I took it to a garage, described the symptoms, they looked at it and said that the mid part of my exhaust was pretty badly corroded and they replaced it for me. got it back the next day and there hasn't been a difference at all. Unfortunatly, I had to rush back up to my uni and couldn't take it back to the garage (Although, they didn't charge me a lot for doing this). It survived the 150 mile journey fine, but now I really want to get this fixed.
Does anyone have any potential problems? I have yet to have a proper look under the bonnet as I've been completely swamped with work, but I have a few hours off tomorrow and will have a look at all cabling and leads under the bonnet.
- Low revs when idling - Exhaust sounds different/not normal (hard to explain the sound, but like a chug) - Loss of power at low revs - Noticeable rise in vibration when idling
I'm not very mechanically inclined, so any further info/reading would be greatly appreciared!!!
Thanks!!

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I have the oddest feeling that this will change into a car forum soon (It would seem appropriate since RS is gey).

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

after i changed the oil on my car once (it was a total mission due to the last owner being a fuckwit), I was driving along happy as larry when suddenly the car turned to shit. It damn turned into a two cylinder. So I just went and ripped all the plug wires out and put them back in (I swapped them around so the original plug 4 wire from spot 4 on the distributor was in spot 1 and plug 1 etc.) It was then running mint again… Still don’t know why it happened.

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

heh, people charge for a scan? crazy

Here, a national auto parts store called AutoZone will not only scan your car for free, they will loan you a scanner to take home for free. (you fully pay for it, and can keep it as long as you like, then take it back for a full refund)

Pretty good system, cause they don’t lose any money, and generally people buy the parts from there too.

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

heh, people charge for a scan? crazy

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @YourNightmare YourNightmare
item.description:
@YourNightmare wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:2, topic:379017”]all of those symptoms seem to point to the engine not firing on all cylinders. it would cause low power, vibrations, and low idle speed. you need to track down which cylinder isnt firing, it could be the spark plug, plug wire, distributor/rotor button/coil, or the coil pack, or possibly even your computer. but start with the simplest thing first, check for broken wires or sparks jumping through cracks (look under the hood with it running in the dark, makes seeing sparks easier), if you dont see anything, take off one wire at a time ans, while the engine is running hold it near a ground point to see if the sparks are at regular intervals like they should be.

alternativly, if you have a place that will scan your car or loan you a scanner for free, and your car is new enough, chances are the scanner will tell you which cylinder is misfiring. i wouldnt pay for a scan though, because its easy to troubleshoot the old fashioned way.[/quote]

In my experience with vehicles I’d agree with mopar on this… you could try checking the plugs and wires to see if one of them may be corroded or something… it could simply be that you need to change them.

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Thanks for the advice, I’ll have a good rummage around under the bonnet tomorrow and see if I can uncover anything. Really hoping that it’s gunna be a quick fix, have hardly any money to be spending on my car right now. Just scraping enough for petrol…

Read full topic

item.title: Having problems with my car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

all of those symptoms seem to point to the engine not firing on all cylinders. it would cause low power, vibrations, and low idle speed. you need to track down which cylinder isnt firing, it could be the spark plug, plug wire, distributor/rotor button/coil, or the coil pack, or possibly even your computer. but start with the simplest thing first, check for broken wires or sparks jumping through cracks (look under the hood with it running in the dark, makes seeing sparks easier), if you dont see anything, take off one wire at a time ans, while the engine is running hold it near a ground point to see if the sparks are at regular intervals like they should be.

alternativly, if you have a place that will scan your car or loan you a scanner for free, and your car is new enough, chances are the scanner will tell you which cylinder is misfiring. i wouldnt pay for a scan though, because its easy to troubleshoot the old fashioned way.

Read full topic

item.description:

C&Ped from another forum
